message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased expression of cellular adhesion molecules in response to injury is a characteristic of inflammation. Among the options, Interleukin-1 is the mediator most directly responsible for the expression of cellular adhesion molecules in inflammation. Interleukin-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine, while Interleukin-6 and Interferon gamma play roles in immune responses but not specifically in the expression of adhesion molecules.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mediators involved in acute inflammation include interleukin-1, interleukin-6, and interleukin-10. However, in response to injury, the expression of cellular adhesion molecules is directly and primarily caused by interleukin-1. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) interleukin-1.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased expression of cellular adhesion molecules is a result of the release of Interleukin-1, which is a pro-inflammatory cytokine involved in the immune response to tissue injury. Interleukin-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine, while Interleukin-6 is involved in the acute phase response to tissue injury. Interferon gamma is a cytokine involved in immune function and defense against pathogens.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The described change is part of the inflammatory response to injury and is mediated by cytokines. Among the options, only Interleukin-1 is a prototypic cytokine and is responsible for inducing endothelial cells to express cellular adhesion molecules.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The described change is consistent with the inflammatory response to tissue injury, which is characterized by the release of cytokines like interleukin-1. Interleukin-10 has anti-inflammatory effects and would not be responsible for the described change. Interleukin-6 plays a role in the acute phase response but is not known to directly cause increased expression of adhesion molecules. Interferon gamma is produced by immune cells and plays a role in antiviral and antimicrobial responses, but is not involved in the acute inflammatory response to tissue injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased expression of cellular adhesion molecules is part of the inflammatory response that occurs after injury. Among the options, Interleukin-1 directly causes endothelial cells to express cellular adhesion molecules, resulting in the recruitment of inflammatory cells to the site of injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The activation of cellular adhesion molecules is due to the release of Interleukin-1 by activated endothelial cells. It promotes inflammation and leukocyte recruitment at the site of tissue injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Interleukin-1 is a cytokine that stimulates the expression of adhesion molecules on endothelial cells, allowing leukocytes to adhere and migrate to the site of injury. This process is important for the recruitment of immune cells to the site of injury to aid in the healing process. Interleukin-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that inhibits the expression of adhesion molecules. Interleukin-6 is a cytokine involved in the inflammatory response, but not specifically in the expression of adhesion molecules. Interferon gamma is a cytokine involved in immune response, but is not typically involved in the early stages of inflammation and wound healing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. After an injury, the body releases cytokines, including interleukin-1, which causes endothelial cells to express increased numbers of cellular adhesion molecules. Among the options, only interleukin-1 is a cytokine and can cause this response.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The described change is characteristic of the acute inflammatory response and is caused by the release of cytokines, including Interleukin-1, by the injured tissue. Among the options, only Interleukin-1 is a cytokine associated with the acute inflammatory response.
